title: Examining Execution Stability at IEX
text: Individual executions are the fundamental units of trading, and the first step in executing a trade is identifying a plan. We can classify the strategies available to the trader into three broad categories based on what price they seek to execute at relative to the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO)Spread-cross ‚Äî e.g: buy a stock by lifting the offer, essentially giving up edge to the seller in return for immediacy and a high degree of certainty around the trade price.Spread-capture ‚Äî e.g: try to buy a stock at the bid or less than the mid. This strategy is a slightly greedy one, as you‚Äôre looking for a deal relative to the best displayed offer. Of course, deal-seeking comes with additional risk of opportunity cost from not finding a willing counterparty.Compromise ‚Äî e.g: try to buy a stock at the midpoint of the NBBO. Here you are not looking for the best possible price relative to the market but instead are trying to meet your counterparty halfway. Naturally, this option falls at a point between the previous two on the risk/reward curve.Using this simple framework comes with complications: not all executions within these categories are equal. For example, a midpoint trade that happens immediately before the midpoint changes is not the same kind of balanced compromise as a trade at the midpoint of a market that is not in transition¬π.Execution stability is an important factor in evaluating how well the intent of a trading strategy is realized.At IEX, we believe that exchange design can play a big role in execution performance. Since our inception, we‚Äôve focused on building technology designed to help traders avoid adverse selection and transact as intended relative to prices that are not imminently changing.And the data shows that we are successful in doing so.Stable Midpoint VolumeIn August 2020, 95.5% of IEX‚Äôs midpoint volume was executed in a stable market, defined as executions not occurring in the 2ms periods before NBBO changes. This compares to 74.8% for Nasdaq, 85.3% for EDGX, 78.9% for NYSE, 77.7% for Arca, and 75.8% for BATS.Calculated using Daily TAQ data from August 2020The main contributor to IEX‚Äôs market-leading level of stable midpoint volume is our Discretionary Peg order type (D-Peg). D-Peg orders benefit from IEX‚Äôs Speed Bump and our Crumbling Quote Indicator (i.e., the CQI or IEX Signal).The Speed Bump delays all incoming orders by 350 microseconds (Œºs) which is designed to give IEX time to determine the most up-to-date NBBO to which we should peg resting orders. The CQI goes further and tries to anticipate a changing NBBO before it happens, allowing resting D-Peg orders to avoid executing during these unstable moments.These two features are designed to work in tandem to enhance the stability of D-Peg trades, but it‚Äôs natural to wonder how they individually contribute to this performance. The following is one way to decompose their impact.Technology Tag-TeamConsider an incoming order that could potentially trade with a resting D-Peg order at IEX. The way this order interacts with the Speed Bump and CQI depends on the state of the market when the incoming order arrived.Consider the following cases:(Speed Bump-Protected) The incoming order arrives within 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move. In this case, without the Speed Bump, we would have pegged a resting D-Peg order at an undesirable price (one that would have changed within 350Œºs). The 350Œºs window afforded by the Speed Bump allows IEX to price the D-Peg order at the midpoint of the newly established, current NBBO.(CQI-Protected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move AND following a correct CQI prediction. In this case, without the CQI, a D-Peg order could have executed at a midpoint that would be stale within 2ms. With the CQI functionality, the D-Peg order would stay booked 1 MPV outside the NBBO, where it is less likely to execute.(Unprotected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move WITHOUT a correct CQI prediction. When IEX is unable to anticipate an upcoming price change, an incoming counterparty has the potential to generate an execution at an unstable price.(Stable NBBO, no protection needed¬≤) The incoming order doesn‚Äôt arrive in a (2ms before, 350Œºs after) window around an NBBO move. In this case, IEX doesn‚Äôt need to do anything special to execute at the intended pegged price, since it is not changing.Note that all marketable-to-mid orders fall within at least one of these cases. For orders that fall into more than one case, we‚Äôll assign them using the priority: CQI-Protected > Speed Bump-protected > Unprotected > Stable.Scenario BreakdownThe following visualizations break down the count of incoming marketable-to-mid¬≥ orders from August 2020 into the above four categories. Each vertical line represents the breakdown of an individual security. First, let‚Äôs look at a set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The symbols are sorted by the percentage of orders in the ‚Äústable‚Äù category; you can see that across symbols, there is a diversity in the percentage of incoming orders received during a stable market.Some symbols, such as GOVT, rarely tick, and therefore most order arrival times are inherently stable and neither the Speed Bump nor CQI play a big role in helping Members trade at the midpoint in a stable market.Other tickers, such as AMZN, are thinly quoted with wide spreads, so the Speed Bump gives IEX the ability to observe the NBBO changes when they happen, while the CQI plays a small role‚Å¥.Finally, there are some heavily quoted tickers, such as SPY, with more structured quote changes, where the CQI interacts with more incoming orders than the Speed Bump alone.Expanding our symbol universe to those that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020, we see that this kind of diversity is widespread:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The Speed Bump and the CQI‚Äôs relevance in preventing adverse selection varies across symbols, but it is the combination of these two technologies that allows us to raise the floor on all symbols by a significant degree. That is, without the Speed Bump or CQI, all of the counterparty orders outside the darkest-blue section could potentially generate unstable executions with our resting D-Peg orders.Another way to think about it is: if IEX did not have the Speed Bump or the CQI, the entire graphic above the darkest blue segment would be red.The Next Frontier in Stable ExecutionsBy appropriately filtering incoming orders across all symbols, the Speed Bump and CQI play a significant role in boosting IEX‚Äôs stable midpoint volume percentage to 95.5%.With stability so high, the natural question is: Where do we go from here?The answer is: to displayed trading. While IEX‚Äôs focus to this point has been on pegged (non-displayed) orders, displayed orders also experience significant levels of adverse selection.In fact, for the aggressive (spread-crossing) contra orders that are eligible to trade with displayed liquidity (a subset of the marketable-to-mid orders considered above), the diversity in the analogous four-category breakdown is even more dramatic. Since displayed limit orders are not pegged to the NBBO, we‚Äôll discard the ‚Äúspeed-bump-protected‚Äù category ‚Äî aggressive orders received in the windows surrounding NBBO changes will either need to be caught by the CQI, or they will count as ‚Äúunprotected.‚ÄùWhen we decompose aggressive orders into the three remaining categories by symbol, we see that the diversity across symbols is even greater. Here is the previously used set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020(This time, we sort by percentage of aggressive orders in the CQI-protected category). And here is the full set of symbols that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020You can see that, compared to counterparties at the midpoint, you have significantly fewer opportunities for a stable execution when your contra is an aggressive order. For most symbols, the fraction of stable contra-orders is less than 30%!However, notice that many of the unstable contra orders are anticipated by the CQI for a large portion of symbols. For example, in TWTR, just 28% of the spread-crossing counterparties arrived during a stable market. Of the remaining unstable orders, nearly 2/3 arrived following a CQI prediction! If we could prevent displayed limit orders from trading with these aggressive orders that were predicted by the CQI, we would have a chance at significantly reducing the number of unstable executions, allowing the orders to achieve true spread capture.On August 26, 2020, the SEC granted approval to IEX‚Äôs Discretionary Limit (D-Limit) order type, which expands the application of the CQI to displayed orders. We view this as a major innovation in displayed trading, and we‚Äôre excited to see how its introduction on October 1 affects the way market participants look for spread capture.IEX is optimistic that using CQI to reduce D-Limit‚Äôs executions during moments of instability will present a competitive option to resting displayed limit orders. We look forward to iterating on this new direction for displayed trading and continuing to develop innovative ways to provide high-quality executions for all market participants.[1] Similarly, buying at the bid is not really achieving true spread capture if that bid becomes the new offer from the NBBO spread shifting downward immediately after the execution. See: Who Ever Said Buy High and Sell Low for an in-depth discussion on how stability can cause the performance of the three categories to blend into each other.[2] As a probabilistic model, the CQI has the potential to ‚Äúincorrectly‚Äù apply protection. False negatives and false positives could restrict a resting D-Peg order‚Äôs discretion in categories 3 + 4 respectively, preventing trades that might have been stable or even in the resting order‚Äôs favor. Despite the potential for these missed opportunities, IEX is able to trade more stable midpoint volume than any other exchange.[3] Marketable-to-mid meaning ‚Äúpriced at least as aggressively as the midpoint of the NBBO.‚Äù Such orders are eligible to transact with resting D-Peg orders.[4] In thinly-quoted names, there is often a single stock exchange at the NBB/NBO. As a result, quote changes are often atomic events that are less predictable. title: Increase your IPO Allotment Chances as a Retail Investor
text: With the decreasing interest rates in bank account deposits, post office deposits, ever-increasing prices of real estate, precious metals, and other ‚Äúsafe‚Äù investment tools, the population is slowly moving their investments towards the stock market.We all know, one of the easiest ways of getting good returns from the stock market is through IPOs(Initial Public Offerings). Companies usually target their IPOs at times of bull rally in the market, when there is high liquidity and people are struggling to find good stocks at reasonable prices. Hence, whenever there is an IPO of a fundamentally strong company coming up in the market, there is a lot of hype, and the IPO is heavily oversubscribed. Yes, there was crazy oversubscription for fundamentally good stocks(at the time of their IPOs) like IRCTC, SBI Cards, Happiest Minds, and a lot more.Most of us are left out with no allotment. However, there are a few tips and tricks that can be followed to increase your chances of allotment:Avoid Technical ErrorsThough most of the trading applications, Demat accounts are well built reactive web applications that help us to minimize human typing errors with their on the go validations, these points are still worth mentioning. Avoid errors in name, PAN number, bank details, etc. If you are applying through ASBA, double check your details like DP id, Demat account number, etc. Make sure the number of shares you apply for is a multiple of the defined number of shares per lot. Also, make sure you do not apply lesser or greater than the range of the number of shares allowed for Retail Investors.Maintain sufficient bank balance before allotmentSome banks block the amount which you are willing to spend to apply for the IPO. However, some do not block any amount and if you do not maintain adequate bank balance, your application will get rejected.One application per PAN numberWhether you have multiple Demat accounts or a single account, make sure that you apply for the IPO only once from just one of your Demat accounts. Multiple applications from one or many Demat accounts using the same PAN number will get all your applications rejected.Apply from multiple Demat accounts through different PAN numbersCreate Demat accounts in the name of your family members, relatives, or friends with their Demat account and you can make applications from their Demat accounts with their PAN numbers. Ensure it is still one application per PAN number.Always apply at the cut-off priceWhen IPOs are oversubscribed, they are going to come at the cut-off price. Avoid defining some price of your own to make sure your application is not rejected.Avoid application on the last day of the issueMost of the QIBs and FIIs and also the Retail Investors do their subscriptions on the last day of the issue based on the market sentiments. This means, there is a lot of load on the bank servers, trading application, etc. which may cause technical problems like UPI mandate notifications not coming up, OTP SMS not coming up, etc. which might make your application invalid. It is always better to apply before-hand, usually IPO sentiments on fundamentally strong companies do not change till the end of the issue date. However, if you have applied and you see that sentiments are looking bad, it may be possible to cancel your application.Apply for IPO allotment reservation quotaVery often, a good amount of shares are reserved for shareholders of the parent company, employees, etc. If you have that privilege, you can make use of it and increase your chances of allocation. You can even buy the parent company‚Äôs share for the short term(within the record date) and then apply for the IPO in the shareholder category. However, this technique may backfire if the parent company is highly favored in the market, in that case, there will be a higher number of people applying for the shareholder category and a lesser number of people in the unreserved category. Whether to apply this technique or not is based on the number of shares reserved for the reserved category and the parent company.Written byKunal KarmakarEnthusiastic Software EngineerFollowStock MarketIPOStock Market TipsInvestmentStock ExchangeMore from Kunal KarmakarFollowEnthusiastic Software EngineerMore From MediumHow to Survive on $800 a MonthKesia Alexandra in The StartupNew York‚Äôs Wack Pet Trust LawAndrea ColemanFree Financial Resources for Better Money in 2020Angely Mercado in Cheap AFStudent Loan Debt: A Sad State of the UnionThe Angry GradSharpe Ratio‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäBigger Isn‚Äôt Necessarily BetterEng Guan Lim in Data Driven InvestorCan You Make A Living As a Day Trader?Jamie Murray in Understanding MoneyMonopoly: Board Game or Our Current Reality?Carter Kilmann in Bacon BitsInvestment Strategies from a Silicon Valley Hedge FundNathan Breiner in The AscentAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

title: STOCK EXCHANGE OR STOCK INDEX?
text: The Difference Between a Stock Exchange and a Stock IndexYou may hear talk about stock exchanges and stock indices, and it‚Äôs easy to confuse them as the same thing. In this article, we highlight what each means and show why they are relevant to your investing strategy. A stock index is a list of stocks that is created to gauge the whole market, or even a sector of the market. A stock exchange, on the other hand, is the actual place where you can buy and sell stocks, bonds, and other securities that are listed on different indices.Let‚Äôs look at some details below.Stock IndicesAn index groups together company stocks in order to measure changes in the broader stock market, or in a sector of the stock market. There are famous examples that you may have heard of, such as the FTSE100. This index includes the 100 largest companies in the UK.Indices can also exist for smaller companies, for example the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is a subsidiary of the London Stock Exchange and allows smaller companies to raise capital with less restrictions. Each index has its own measure of how exactly it‚Äôs valued. This could be based on the cumulative share price of the individual stocks, or it could be based on the total market capitalisation in the index. Some even combine both measurements. As the individual share prices or market caps move up and down within the index, the total value of the individual index changes too.Stock ExchangesIf you actually want to buy a stock, then you‚Äôll have to turn to an exchange. One of the largest and most famous stock exchanges in the world is headquartered in the UK: the London Stock Exchange. There are exchanges all over the world, including the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, the B3 in Brazil, and the New York Stock Exchange in the US. title: Examining Execution Stability at IEX
text: Individual executions are the fundamental units of trading, and the first step in executing a trade is identifying a plan. We can classify the strategies available to the trader into three broad categories based on what price they seek to execute at relative to the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO)Spread-cross ‚Äî e.g: buy a stock by lifting the offer, essentially giving up edge to the seller in return for immediacy and a high degree of certainty around the trade price.Spread-capture ‚Äî e.g: try to buy a stock at the bid or less than the mid. This strategy is a slightly greedy one, as you‚Äôre looking for a deal relative to the best displayed offer. Of course, deal-seeking comes with additional risk of opportunity cost from not finding a willing counterparty.Compromise ‚Äî e.g: try to buy a stock at the midpoint of the NBBO. Here you are not looking for the best possible price relative to the market but instead are trying to meet your counterparty halfway. Naturally, this option falls at a point between the previous two on the risk/reward curve.Using this simple framework comes with complications: not all executions within these categories are equal. For example, a midpoint trade that happens immediately before the midpoint changes is not the same kind of balanced compromise as a trade at the midpoint of a market that is not in transition¬π.Execution stability is an important factor in evaluating how well the intent of a trading strategy is realized.At IEX, we believe that exchange design can play a big role in execution performance. Since our inception, we‚Äôve focused on building technology designed to help traders avoid adverse selection and transact as intended relative to prices that are not imminently changing.And the data shows that we are successful in doing so.Stable Midpoint VolumeIn August 2020, 95.5% of IEX‚Äôs midpoint volume was executed in a stable market, defined as executions not occurring in the 2ms periods before NBBO changes. This compares to 74.8% for Nasdaq, 85.3% for EDGX, 78.9% for NYSE, 77.7% for Arca, and 75.8% for BATS.Calculated using Daily TAQ data from August 2020The main contributor to IEX‚Äôs market-leading level of stable midpoint volume is our Discretionary Peg order type (D-Peg). D-Peg orders benefit from IEX‚Äôs Speed Bump and our Crumbling Quote Indicator (i.e., the CQI or IEX Signal).The Speed Bump delays all incoming orders by 350 microseconds (Œºs) which is designed to give IEX time to determine the most up-to-date NBBO to which we should peg resting orders. The CQI goes further and tries to anticipate a changing NBBO before it happens, allowing resting D-Peg orders to avoid executing during these unstable moments.These two features are designed to work in tandem to enhance the stability of D-Peg trades, but it‚Äôs natural to wonder how they individually contribute to this performance. The following is one way to decompose their impact.Technology Tag-TeamConsider an incoming order that could potentially trade with a resting D-Peg order at IEX. The way this order interacts with the Speed Bump and CQI depends on the state of the market when the incoming order arrived.Consider the following cases:(Speed Bump-Protected) The incoming order arrives within 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move. In this case, without the Speed Bump, we would have pegged a resting D-Peg order at an undesirable price (one that would have changed within 350Œºs). The 350Œºs window afforded by the Speed Bump allows IEX to price the D-Peg order at the midpoint of the newly established, current NBBO.(CQI-Protected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move AND following a correct CQI prediction. In this case, without the CQI, a D-Peg order could have executed at a midpoint that would be stale within 2ms. With the CQI functionality, the D-Peg order would stay booked 1 MPV outside the NBBO, where it is less likely to execute.(Unprotected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move WITHOUT a correct CQI prediction. When IEX is unable to anticipate an upcoming price change, an incoming counterparty has the potential to generate an execution at an unstable price.(Stable NBBO, no protection needed¬≤) The incoming order doesn‚Äôt arrive in a (2ms before, 350Œºs after) window around an NBBO move. In this case, IEX doesn‚Äôt need to do anything special to execute at the intended pegged price, since it is not changing.Note that all marketable-to-mid orders fall within at least one of these cases. For orders that fall into more than one case, we‚Äôll assign them using the priority: CQI-Protected > Speed Bump-protected > Unprotected > Stable.Scenario BreakdownThe following visualizations break down the count of incoming marketable-to-mid¬≥ orders from August 2020 into the above four categories. Each vertical line represents the breakdown of an individual security. First, let‚Äôs look at a set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The symbols are sorted by the percentage of orders in the ‚Äústable‚Äù category; you can see that across symbols, there is a diversity in the percentage of incoming orders received during a stable market.Some symbols, such as GOVT, rarely tick, and therefore most order arrival times are inherently stable and neither the Speed Bump nor CQI play a big role in helping Members trade at the midpoint in a stable market.Other tickers, such as AMZN, are thinly quoted with wide spreads, so the Speed Bump gives IEX the ability to observe the NBBO changes when they happen, while the CQI plays a small role‚Å¥.Finally, there are some heavily quoted tickers, such as SPY, with more structured quote changes, where the CQI interacts with more incoming orders than the Speed Bump alone.Expanding our symbol universe to those that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020, we see that this kind of diversity is widespread:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The Speed Bump and the CQI‚Äôs relevance in preventing adverse selection varies across symbols, but it is the combination of these two technologies that allows us to raise the floor on all symbols by a significant degree. That is, without the Speed Bump or CQI, all of the counterparty orders outside the darkest-blue section could potentially generate unstable executions with our resting D-Peg orders.Another way to think about it is: if IEX did not have the Speed Bump or the CQI, the entire graphic above the darkest blue segment would be red.The Next Frontier in Stable ExecutionsBy appropriately filtering incoming orders across all symbols, the Speed Bump and CQI play a significant role in boosting IEX‚Äôs stable midpoint volume percentage to 95.5%.With stability so high, the natural question is: Where do we go from here?The answer is: to displayed trading. While IEX‚Äôs focus to this point has been on pegged (non-displayed) orders, displayed orders also experience significant levels of adverse selection.In fact, for the aggressive (spread-crossing) contra orders that are eligible to trade with displayed liquidity (a subset of the marketable-to-mid orders considered above), the diversity in the analogous four-category breakdown is even more dramatic. Since displayed limit orders are not pegged to the NBBO, we‚Äôll discard the ‚Äúspeed-bump-protected‚Äù category ‚Äî aggressive orders received in the windows surrounding NBBO changes will either need to be caught by the CQI, or they will count as ‚Äúunprotected.‚ÄùWhen we decompose aggressive orders into the three remaining categories by symbol, we see that the diversity across symbols is even greater. Here is the previously used set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020(This time, we sort by percentage of aggressive orders in the CQI-protected category). And here is the full set of symbols that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020You can see that, compared to counterparties at the midpoint, you have significantly fewer opportunities for a stable execution when your contra is an aggressive order. For most symbols, the fraction of stable contra-orders is less than 30%!However, notice that many of the unstable contra orders are anticipated by the CQI for a large portion of symbols. For example, in TWTR, just 28% of the spread-crossing counterparties arrived during a stable market. Of the remaining unstable orders, nearly 2/3 arrived following a CQI prediction! If we could prevent displayed limit orders from trading with these aggressive orders that were predicted by the CQI, we would have a chance at significantly reducing the number of unstable executions, allowing the orders to achieve true spread capture.On August 26, 2020, the SEC granted approval to IEX‚Äôs Discretionary Limit (D-Limit) order type, which expands the application of the CQI to displayed orders. We view this as a major innovation in displayed trading, and we‚Äôre excited to see how its introduction on October 1 affects the way market participants look for spread capture.IEX is optimistic that using CQI to reduce D-Limit‚Äôs executions during moments of instability will present a competitive option to resting displayed limit orders. We look forward to iterating on this new direction for displayed trading and continuing to develop innovative ways to provide high-quality executions for all market participants.[1] Similarly, buying at the bid is not really achieving true spread capture if that bid becomes the new offer from the NBBO spread shifting downward immediately after the execution. See: Who Ever Said Buy High and Sell Low for an in-depth discussion on how stability can cause the performance of the three categories to blend into each other.[2] As a probabilistic model, the CQI has the potential to ‚Äúincorrectly‚Äù apply protection. False negatives and false positives could restrict a resting D-Peg order‚Äôs discretion in categories 3 + 4 respectively, preventing trades that might have been stable or even in the resting order‚Äôs favor. Despite the potential for these missed opportunities, IEX is able to trade more stable midpoint volume than any other exchange.[3] Marketable-to-mid meaning ‚Äúpriced at least as aggressively as the midpoint of the NBBO.‚Äù Such orders are eligible to transact with resting D-Peg orders.[4] In thinly-quoted names, there is often a single stock exchange at the NBB/NBO. As a result, quote changes are often atomic events that are less predictable. For more, see ‚Äúlonely quotes‚Äù here.About IEX ExchangeIEX Exchange is a U.S. stock exchange designed to provide superior execution quality and set a new standard for trading. title: Increase your IPO Allotment Chances as a Retail Investor
text: With the decreasing interest rates in bank account deposits, post office deposits, ever-increasing prices of real estate, precious metals, and other ‚Äúsafe‚Äù investment tools, the population is slowly moving their investments towards the stock market.We all know, one of the easiest ways of getting good returns from the stock market is through IPOs(Initial Public Offerings). Companies usually target their IPOs at times of bull rally in the market, when there is high liquidity and people are struggling to find good stocks at reasonable prices. Hence, whenever there is an IPO of a fundamentally strong company coming up in the market, there is a lot of hype, and the IPO is heavily oversubscribed. Yes, there was crazy oversubscription for fundamentally good stocks(at the time of their IPOs) like IRCTC, SBI Cards, Happiest Minds, and a lot more.Most of us are left out with no allotment. However, there are a few tips and tricks that can be followed to increase your chances of allotment:Avoid Technical ErrorsThough most of the trading applications, Demat accounts are well built reactive web applications that help us to minimize human typing errors with their on the go validations, these points are still worth mentioning. Avoid errors in name, PAN number, bank details, etc. If you are applying through ASBA, double check your details like DP id, Demat account number, etc. Make sure the number of shares you apply for is a multiple of the defined number of shares per lot. Also, make sure you do not apply lesser or greater than the range of the number of shares allowed for Retail Investors.Maintain sufficient bank balance before allotmentSome banks block the amount which you are willing to spend to apply for the IPO. However, some do not block any amount and if you do not maintain adequate bank balance, your application will get rejected.One application per PAN numberWhether you have multiple Demat accounts or a single account, make sure that you apply for the IPO only once from just one of your Demat accounts. Multiple applications from one or many Demat accounts using the same PAN number will get all your applications rejected.Apply from multiple Demat accounts through different PAN numbersCreate Demat accounts in the name of your family members, relatives, or friends with their Demat account and you can make applications from their Demat accounts with their PAN numbers. Ensure it is still one application per PAN number.Always apply at the cut-off priceWhen IPOs are oversubscribed, they are going to come at the cut-off price. Avoid defining some price of your own to make sure your application is not rejected.Avoid application on the last day of the issueMost of the QIBs and FIIs and also the Retail Investors do their subscriptions on the last day of the issue based on the market sentiments. This means, there is a lot of load on the bank servers, trading application, etc. which may cause technical problems like UPI mandate notifications not coming up, OTP SMS not coming up, etc. which might make your application invalid. It is always better to apply before-hand, usually IPO sentiments on fundamentally strong companies do not change till the end of the issue date. However, if you have applied and you see that sentiments are looking bad, it may be possible to cancel your application.Apply for IPO allotment reservation quotaVery often, a good amount of shares are reserved for shareholders of the parent company, employees, etc. If you have that privilege, you can make use of it and increase your chances of allocation. You can even buy the parent company‚Äôs share for the short term(within the record date) and then apply for the IPO in the shareholder category. However, this technique may backfire if the parent company is highly favored in the market, in that case, there will be a higher number of people applying for the shareholder category and a lesser number of people in the unreserved category. Whether to apply this technique or not is based on the number of shares reserved for the reserved category and the parent company.Written byKunal KarmakarEnthusiastic Software EngineerFollowStock MarketIPOStock Market TipsInvestmentStock ExchangeMore from Kunal KarmakarFollowEnthusiastic Software EngineerMore From MediumHow Do We Measure Investment Performance?Farhad Malik in FinTechExplainedYou never forget the time when you were poorKelly Tompkins in The Startup3 Ways to Build Income Streams (Right Now)Envy Writer in Not Poor AnymoreThe Cruelest Social Experiment in the History of MoneyRocco Pendola in Making of a Millionaire3 Reasons Why You Can‚Äôt Save MoneyRocco Pendola in Making of a MillionaireDon‚Äôt Buy that Cup of CoffeeAaron Schnoor in The Intelligence of EverythingWhy Entrepreneurs Should Spend Time Earning a Passive IncomeCalendar in CalendarYou Don‚Äôt Need a Budget, You Just Need These Two AccountsKelley C. title: STOCK EXCHANGE OR STOCK INDEX?
text: The Difference Between a Stock Exchange and a Stock IndexYou may hear talk about stock exchanges and stock indices, and it‚Äôs easy to confuse them as the same thing. In this article, we highlight what each means and show why they are relevant to your investing strategy. A stock index is a list of stocks that is created to gauge the whole market, or even a sector of the market. A stock exchange, on the other hand, is the actual place where you can buy and sell stocks, bonds, and other securities that are listed on different indices.Let‚Äôs look at some details below.Stock IndicesAn index groups together company stocks in order to measure changes in the broader stock market, or in a sector of the stock market. There are famous examples that you may have heard of, such as the FTSE100. This index includes the 100 largest companies in the UK.Indices can also exist for smaller companies, for example the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is a subsidiary of the London Stock Exchange and allows smaller companies to raise capital with less restrictions. Each index has its own measure of how exactly it‚Äôs valued. This could be based on the cumulative share price of the individual stocks, or it could be based on the total market capitalisation in the index. Some even combine both measurements. As the individual share prices or market caps move up and down within the index, the total value of the individual index changes too.Stock ExchangesIf you actually want to buy a stock, then you‚Äôll have to turn to an exchange. One of the largest and most famous stock exchanges in the world is headquartered in the UK: the London Stock Exchange. There are exchanges all over the world, including the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, the B3 in Brazil, and the New York Stock Exchange in the US. title: Examining Execution Stability at IEX
text: Individual executions are the fundamental units of trading, and the first step in executing a trade is identifying a plan. We can classify the strategies available to the trader into three broad categories based on what price they seek to execute at relative to the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO)Spread-cross ‚Äî e.g: buy a stock by lifting the offer, essentially giving up edge to the seller in return for immediacy and a high degree of certainty around the trade price.Spread-capture ‚Äî e.g: try to buy a stock at the bid or less than the mid. This strategy is a slightly greedy one, as you‚Äôre looking for a deal relative to the best displayed offer. Of course, deal-seeking comes with additional risk of opportunity cost from not finding a willing counterparty.Compromise ‚Äî e.g: try to buy a stock at the midpoint of the NBBO. Here you are not looking for the best possible price relative to the market but instead are trying to meet your counterparty halfway. Naturally, this option falls at a point between the previous two on the risk/reward curve.Using this simple framework comes with complications: not all executions within these categories are equal. For example, a midpoint trade that happens immediately before the midpoint changes is not the same kind of balanced compromise as a trade at the midpoint of a market that is not in transition¬π.Execution stability is an important factor in evaluating how well the intent of a trading strategy is realized.At IEX, we believe that exchange design can play a big role in execution performance. Since our inception, we‚Äôve focused on building technology designed to help traders avoid adverse selection and transact as intended relative to prices that are not imminently changing.And the data shows that we are successful in doing so.Stable Midpoint VolumeIn August 2020, 95.5% of IEX‚Äôs midpoint volume was executed in a stable market, defined as executions not occurring in the 2ms periods before NBBO changes. This compares to 74.8% for Nasdaq, 85.3% for EDGX, 78.9% for NYSE, 77.7% for Arca, and 75.8% for BATS.Calculated using Daily TAQ data from August 2020The main contributor to IEX‚Äôs market-leading level of stable midpoint volume is our Discretionary Peg order type (D-Peg). D-Peg orders benefit from IEX‚Äôs Speed Bump and our Crumbling Quote Indicator (i.e., the CQI or IEX Signal).The Speed Bump delays all incoming orders by 350 microseconds (Œºs) which is designed to give IEX time to determine the most up-to-date NBBO to which we should peg resting orders. The CQI goes further and tries to anticipate a changing NBBO before it happens, allowing resting D-Peg orders to avoid executing during these unstable moments.These two features are designed to work in tandem to enhance the stability of D-Peg trades, but it‚Äôs natural to wonder how they individually contribute to this performance. The following is one way to decompose their impact.Technology Tag-TeamConsider an incoming order that could potentially trade with a resting D-Peg order at IEX. The way this order interacts with the Speed Bump and CQI depends on the state of the market when the incoming order arrived.Consider the following cases:(Speed Bump-Protected) The incoming order arrives within 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move. In this case, without the Speed Bump, we would have pegged a resting D-Peg order at an undesirable price (one that would have changed within 350Œºs). The 350Œºs window afforded by the Speed Bump allows IEX to price the D-Peg order at the midpoint of the newly established, current NBBO.(CQI-Protected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move AND following a correct CQI prediction. In this case, without the CQI, a D-Peg order could have executed at a midpoint that would be stale within 2ms. With the CQI functionality, the D-Peg order would stay booked 1 MPV outside the NBBO, where it is less likely to execute.(Unprotected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move WITHOUT a correct CQI prediction. When IEX is unable to anticipate an upcoming price change, an incoming counterparty has the potential to generate an execution at an unstable price.(Stable NBBO, no protection needed¬≤) The incoming order doesn‚Äôt arrive in a (2ms before, 350Œºs after) window around an NBBO move. In this case, IEX doesn‚Äôt need to do anything special to execute at the intended pegged price, since it is not changing.Note that all marketable-to-mid orders fall within at least one of these cases. For orders that fall into more than one case, we‚Äôll assign them using the priority: CQI-Protected > Speed Bump-protected > Unprotected > Stable.Scenario BreakdownThe following visualizations break down the count of incoming marketable-to-mid¬≥ orders from August 2020 into the above four categories. Each vertical line represents the breakdown of an individual security. First, let‚Äôs look at a set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The symbols are sorted by the percentage of orders in the ‚Äústable‚Äù category; you can see that across symbols, there is a diversity in the percentage of incoming orders received during a stable market.Some symbols, such as GOVT, rarely tick, and therefore most order arrival times are inherently stable and neither the Speed Bump nor CQI play a big role in helping Members trade at the midpoint in a stable market.Other tickers, such as AMZN, are thinly quoted with wide spreads, so the Speed Bump gives IEX the ability to observe the NBBO changes when they happen, while the CQI plays a small role‚Å¥.Finally, there are some heavily quoted tickers, such as SPY, with more structured quote changes, where the CQI interacts with more incoming orders than the Speed Bump alone.Expanding our symbol universe to those that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020, we see that this kind of diversity is widespread:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The Speed Bump and the CQI‚Äôs relevance in preventing adverse selection varies across symbols, but it is the combination of these two technologies that allows us to raise the floor on all symbols by a significant degree. That is, without the Speed Bump or CQI, all of the counterparty orders outside the darkest-blue section could potentially generate unstable executions with our resting D-Peg orders.Another way to think about it is: if IEX did not have the Speed Bump or the CQI, the entire graphic above the darkest blue segment would be red.The Next Frontier in Stable ExecutionsBy appropriately filtering incoming orders across all symbols, the Speed Bump and CQI play a significant role in boosting IEX‚Äôs stable midpoint volume percentage to 95.5%.With stability so high, the natural question is: Where do we go from here?The answer is: to displayed trading. While IEX‚Äôs focus to this point has been on pegged (non-displayed) orders, displayed orders also experience significant levels of adverse selection.In fact, for the aggressive (spread-crossing) contra orders that are eligible to trade with displayed liquidity (a subset of the marketable-to-mid orders considered above), the diversity in the analogous four-category breakdown is even more dramatic. Since displayed limit orders are not pegged to the NBBO, we‚Äôll discard the ‚Äúspeed-bump-protected‚Äù category ‚Äî aggressive orders received in the windows surrounding NBBO changes will either need to be caught by the CQI, or they will count as ‚Äúunprotected.‚ÄùWhen we decompose aggressive orders into the three remaining categories by symbol, we see that the diversity across symbols is even greater. Here is the previously used set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020(This time, we sort by percentage of aggressive orders in the CQI-protected category). And here is the full set of symbols that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020You can see that, compared to counterparties at the midpoint, you have significantly fewer opportunities for a stable execution when your contra is an aggressive order. For most symbols, the fraction of stable contra-orders is less than 30%!However, notice that many of the unstable contra orders are anticipated by the CQI for a large portion of symbols. For example, in TWTR, just 28% of the spread-crossing counterparties arrived during a stable market. Of the remaining unstable orders, nearly 2/3 arrived following a CQI prediction! If we could prevent displayed limit orders from trading with these aggressive orders that were predicted by the CQI, we would have a chance at significantly reducing the number of unstable executions, allowing the orders to achieve true spread capture.On August 26, 2020, the SEC granted approval to IEX‚Äôs Discretionary Limit (D-Limit) order type, which expands the application of the CQI to displayed orders. We view this as a major innovation in displayed trading, and we‚Äôre excited to see how its introduction on October 1 affects the way market participants look for spread capture.IEX is optimistic that using CQI to reduce D-Limit‚Äôs executions during moments of instability will present a competitive option to resting displayed limit orders. We look forward to iterating on this new direction for displayed trading and continuing to develop innovative ways to provide high-quality executions for all market participants.[1] Similarly, buying at the bid is not really achieving true spread capture if that bid becomes the new offer from the NBBO spread shifting downward immediately after the execution. See: Who Ever Said Buy High and Sell Low for an in-depth discussion on how stability can cause the performance of the three categories to blend into each other.[2] As a probabilistic model, the CQI has the potential to ‚Äúincorrectly‚Äù apply protection. False negatives and false positives could restrict a resting D-Peg order‚Äôs discretion in categories 3 + 4 respectively, preventing trades that might have been stable or even in the resting order‚Äôs favor. Despite the potential for these missed opportunities, IEX is able to trade more stable midpoint volume than any other exchange.[3] Marketable-to-mid meaning ‚Äúpriced at least as aggressively as the midpoint of the NBBO.‚Äù Such orders are eligible to transact with resting D-Peg orders.[4] In thinly-quoted names, there is often a single stock exchange at the NBB/NBO. As a result, quote changes are often atomic events that are less predictable. For more, see ‚Äúlonely quotes‚Äù here.About IEX ExchangeIEX Exchange is a U.S. stock exchange designed to provide superior execution quality and set a new standard for trading. title: Increase your IPO Allotment Chances as a Retail Investor
text: With the decreasing interest rates in bank account deposits, post office deposits, ever-increasing prices of real estate, precious metals, and other ‚Äúsafe‚Äù investment tools, the population is slowly moving their investments towards the stock market.We all know, one of the easiest ways of getting good returns from the stock market is through IPOs(Initial Public Offerings). Companies usually target their IPOs at times of bull rally in the market, when there is high liquidity and people are struggling to find good stocks at reasonable prices. Hence, whenever there is an IPO of a fundamentally strong company coming up in the market, there is a lot of hype, and the IPO is heavily oversubscribed. Yes, there was crazy oversubscription for fundamentally good stocks(at the time of their IPOs) like IRCTC, SBI Cards, Happiest Minds, and a lot more.Most of us are left out with no allotment. However, there are a few tips and tricks that can be followed to increase your chances of allotment:Avoid Technical ErrorsThough most of the trading applications, Demat accounts are well built reactive web applications that help us to minimize human typing errors with their on the go validations, these points are still worth mentioning. Avoid errors in name, PAN number, bank details, etc. If you are applying through ASBA, double check your details like DP id, Demat account number, etc. Make sure the number of shares you apply for is a multiple of the defined number of shares per lot. Also, make sure you do not apply lesser or greater than the range of the number of shares allowed for Retail Investors.Maintain sufficient bank balance before allotmentSome banks block the amount which you are willing to spend to apply for the IPO. However, some do not block any amount and if you do not maintain adequate bank balance, your application will get rejected.One application per PAN numberWhether you have multiple Demat accounts or a single account, make sure that you apply for the IPO only once from just one of your Demat accounts. Multiple applications from one or many Demat accounts using the same PAN number will get all your applications rejected.Apply from multiple Demat accounts through different PAN numbersCreate Demat accounts in the name of your family members, relatives, or friends with their Demat account and you can make applications from their Demat accounts with their PAN numbers. Ensure it is still one application per PAN number.Always apply at the cut-off priceWhen IPOs are oversubscribed, they are going to come at the cut-off price. Avoid defining some price of your own to make sure your application is not rejected.Avoid application on the last day of the issueMost of the QIBs and FIIs and also the Retail Investors do their subscriptions on the last day of the issue based on the market sentiments. This means, there is a lot of load on the bank servers, trading application, etc. which may cause technical problems like UPI mandate notifications not coming up, OTP SMS not coming up, etc. which might make your application invalid. It is always better to apply before-hand, usually IPO sentiments on fundamentally strong companies do not change till the end of the issue date. However, if you have applied and you see that sentiments are looking bad, it may be possible to cancel your application.Apply for IPO allotment reservation quotaVery often, a good amount of shares are reserved for shareholders of the parent company, employees, etc. If you have that privilege, you can make use of it and increase your chances of allocation. You can even buy the parent company‚Äôs share for the short term(within the record date) and then apply for the IPO in the shareholder category. However, this technique may backfire if the parent company is highly favored in the market, in that case, there will be a higher number of people applying for the shareholder category and a lesser number of people in the unreserved category. Whether to apply this technique or not is based on the number of shares reserved for the reserved category and the parent company.Written byKunal KarmakarEnthusiastic Software EngineerFollowStock MarketIPOStock Market TipsInvestmentStock ExchangeMore from Kunal KarmakarFollowEnthusiastic Software EngineerMore From MediumHow to Survive on $800 a MonthKesia Alexandra in The StartupNew York‚Äôs Wack Pet Trust LawAndrea ColemanFree Financial Resources for Better Money in 2020Angely Mercado in Cheap AFStudent Loan Debt: A Sad State of the UnionThe Angry GradSharpe Ratio‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäBigger Isn‚Äôt Necessarily BetterEng Guan Lim in Data Driven InvestorCan You Make A Living As a Day Trader?Jamie Murray in Understanding MoneyMonopoly: Board Game or Our Current Reality?Carter Kilmann in Bacon BitsInvestment Strategies from a Silicon Valley Hedge FundNathan Breiner in The AscentAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

title: STOCK EXCHANGE OR STOCK INDEX?
text: The Difference Between a Stock Exchange and a Stock IndexYou may hear talk about stock exchanges and stock indices, and it‚Äôs easy to confuse them as the same thing. In this article, we highlight what each means and show why they are relevant to your investing strategy. A stock index is a list of stocks that is created to gauge the whole market, or even a sector of the market. A stock exchange, on the other hand, is the actual place where you can buy and sell stocks, bonds, and other securities that are listed on different indices.Let‚Äôs look at some details below.Stock IndicesAn index groups together company stocks in order to measure changes in the broader stock market, or in a sector of the stock market. There are famous examples that you may have heard of, such as the FTSE100. This index includes the 100 largest companies in the UK.Indices can also exist for smaller companies, for example the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is a subsidiary of the London Stock Exchange and allows smaller companies to raise capital with less restrictions. Each index has its own measure of how exactly it‚Äôs valued. This could be based on the cumulative share price of the individual stocks, or it could be based on the total market capitalisation in the index. Some even combine both measurements. As the individual share prices or market caps move up and down within the index, the total value of the individual index changes too.Stock ExchangesIf you actually want to buy a stock, then you‚Äôll have to turn to an exchange. One of the largest and most famous stock exchanges in the world is headquartered in the UK: the London Stock Exchange. There are exchanges all over the world, including the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, the B3 in Brazil, and the New York Stock Exchange in the US. It is recommended that you employ a stock brokerage firm that deals with domestic and foreign markets.In addition to doing research about the companies you plan to do stock trading with Internationally, you will want to check out the legitimacy of the brokerage firm you plan to work with. While the internet opens the door to new opportunities such as this, it has also opened the doors wide open for all types of scams and fraud.Online stockbrokers will provide you with the information you need for successful international online stock trading. title: Examining Execution Stability at IEX
text: Individual executions are the fundamental units of trading, and the first step in executing a trade is identifying a plan. We can classify the strategies available to the trader into three broad categories based on what price they seek to execute at relative to the National Best Bid and Offer (NBBO)Spread-cross ‚Äî e.g: buy a stock by lifting the offer, essentially giving up edge to the seller in return for immediacy and a high degree of certainty around the trade price.Spread-capture ‚Äî e.g: try to buy a stock at the bid or less than the mid. This strategy is a slightly greedy one, as you‚Äôre looking for a deal relative to the best displayed offer. Of course, deal-seeking comes with additional risk of opportunity cost from not finding a willing counterparty.Compromise ‚Äî e.g: try to buy a stock at the midpoint of the NBBO. Here you are not looking for the best possible price relative to the market but instead are trying to meet your counterparty halfway. Naturally, this option falls at a point between the previous two on the risk/reward curve.Using this simple framework comes with complications: not all executions within these categories are equal. For example, a midpoint trade that happens immediately before the midpoint changes is not the same kind of balanced compromise as a trade at the midpoint of a market that is not in transition¬π.Execution stability is an important factor in evaluating how well the intent of a trading strategy is realized.At IEX, we believe that exchange design can play a big role in execution performance. Since our inception, we‚Äôve focused on building technology designed to help traders avoid adverse selection and transact as intended relative to prices that are not imminently changing.And the data shows that we are successful in doing so.Stable Midpoint VolumeIn August 2020, 95.5% of IEX‚Äôs midpoint volume was executed in a stable market, defined as executions not occurring in the 2ms periods before NBBO changes. This compares to 74.8% for Nasdaq, 85.3% for EDGX, 78.9% for NYSE, 77.7% for Arca, and 75.8% for BATS.Calculated using Daily TAQ data from August 2020The main contributor to IEX‚Äôs market-leading level of stable midpoint volume is our Discretionary Peg order type (D-Peg). D-Peg orders benefit from IEX‚Äôs Speed Bump and our Crumbling Quote Indicator (i.e., the CQI or IEX Signal).The Speed Bump delays all incoming orders by 350 microseconds (Œºs) which is designed to give IEX time to determine the most up-to-date NBBO to which we should peg resting orders. The CQI goes further and tries to anticipate a changing NBBO before it happens, allowing resting D-Peg orders to avoid executing during these unstable moments.These two features are designed to work in tandem to enhance the stability of D-Peg trades, but it‚Äôs natural to wonder how they individually contribute to this performance. The following is one way to decompose their impact.Technology Tag-TeamConsider an incoming order that could potentially trade with a resting D-Peg order at IEX. The way this order interacts with the Speed Bump and CQI depends on the state of the market when the incoming order arrived.Consider the following cases:(Speed Bump-Protected) The incoming order arrives within 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move. In this case, without the Speed Bump, we would have pegged a resting D-Peg order at an undesirable price (one that would have changed within 350Œºs). The 350Œºs window afforded by the Speed Bump allows IEX to price the D-Peg order at the midpoint of the newly established, current NBBO.(CQI-Protected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move AND following a correct CQI prediction. In this case, without the CQI, a D-Peg order could have executed at a midpoint that would be stale within 2ms. With the CQI functionality, the D-Peg order would stay booked 1 MPV outside the NBBO, where it is less likely to execute.(Unprotected) The incoming order arrives between 2ms before and 350Œºs after IEX sees an NBBO move WITHOUT a correct CQI prediction. When IEX is unable to anticipate an upcoming price change, an incoming counterparty has the potential to generate an execution at an unstable price.(Stable NBBO, no protection needed¬≤) The incoming order doesn‚Äôt arrive in a (2ms before, 350Œºs after) window around an NBBO move. In this case, IEX doesn‚Äôt need to do anything special to execute at the intended pegged price, since it is not changing.Note that all marketable-to-mid orders fall within at least one of these cases. For orders that fall into more than one case, we‚Äôll assign them using the priority: CQI-Protected > Speed Bump-protected > Unprotected > Stable.Scenario BreakdownThe following visualizations break down the count of incoming marketable-to-mid¬≥ orders from August 2020 into the above four categories. Each vertical line represents the breakdown of an individual security. First, let‚Äôs look at a set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The symbols are sorted by the percentage of orders in the ‚Äústable‚Äù category; you can see that across symbols, there is a diversity in the percentage of incoming orders received during a stable market.Some symbols, such as GOVT, rarely tick, and therefore most order arrival times are inherently stable and neither the Speed Bump nor CQI play a big role in helping Members trade at the midpoint in a stable market.Other tickers, such as AMZN, are thinly quoted with wide spreads, so the Speed Bump gives IEX the ability to observe the NBBO changes when they happen, while the CQI plays a small role‚Å¥.Finally, there are some heavily quoted tickers, such as SPY, with more structured quote changes, where the CQI interacts with more incoming orders than the Speed Bump alone.Expanding our symbol universe to those that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020, we see that this kind of diversity is widespread:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020The Speed Bump and the CQI‚Äôs relevance in preventing adverse selection varies across symbols, but it is the combination of these two technologies that allows us to raise the floor on all symbols by a significant degree. That is, without the Speed Bump or CQI, all of the counterparty orders outside the darkest-blue section could potentially generate unstable executions with our resting D-Peg orders.Another way to think about it is: if IEX did not have the Speed Bump or the CQI, the entire graphic above the darkest blue segment would be red.The Next Frontier in Stable ExecutionsBy appropriately filtering incoming orders across all symbols, the Speed Bump and CQI play a significant role in boosting IEX‚Äôs stable midpoint volume percentage to 95.5%.With stability so high, the natural question is: Where do we go from here?The answer is: to displayed trading. While IEX‚Äôs focus to this point has been on pegged (non-displayed) orders, displayed orders also experience significant levels of adverse selection.In fact, for the aggressive (spread-crossing) contra orders that are eligible to trade with displayed liquidity (a subset of the marketable-to-mid orders considered above), the diversity in the analogous four-category breakdown is even more dramatic. Since displayed limit orders are not pegged to the NBBO, we‚Äôll discard the ‚Äúspeed-bump-protected‚Äù category ‚Äî aggressive orders received in the windows surrounding NBBO changes will either need to be caught by the CQI, or they will count as ‚Äúunprotected.‚ÄùWhen we decompose aggressive orders into the three remaining categories by symbol, we see that the diversity across symbols is even greater. Here is the previously used set of well-known symbols:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020(This time, we sort by percentage of aggressive orders in the CQI-protected category). And here is the full set of symbols that traded an average daily notional value of at least $50M over the month of August 2020:Source: IEX Market Data, August 2020You can see that, compared to counterparties at the midpoint, you have significantly fewer opportunities for a stable execution when your contra is an aggressive order. For most symbols, the fraction of stable contra-orders is less than 30%!However, notice that many of the unstable contra orders are anticipated by the CQI for a large portion of symbols. For example, in TWTR, just 28% of the spread-crossing counterparties arrived during a stable market. Of the remaining unstable orders, nearly 2/3 arrived following a CQI prediction! If we could prevent displayed limit orders from trading with these aggressive orders that were predicted by the CQI, we would have a chance at significantly reducing the number of unstable executions, allowing the orders to achieve true spread capture.On August 26, 2020, the SEC granted approval to IEX‚Äôs Discretionary Limit (D-Limit) order type, which expands the application of the CQI to displayed orders. We view this as a major innovation in displayed trading, and we‚Äôre excited to see how its introduction on October 1 affects the way market participants look for spread capture.IEX is optimistic that using CQI to reduce D-Limit‚Äôs executions during moments of instability will present a competitive option to resting displayed limit orders. We look forward to iterating on this new direction for displayed trading and continuing to develop innovative ways to provide high-quality executions for all market participants.[1] Similarly, buying at the bid is not really achieving true spread capture if that bid becomes the new offer from the NBBO spread shifting downward immediately after the execution. See: Who Ever Said Buy High and Sell Low for an in-depth discussion on how stability can cause the performance of the three categories to blend into each other.[2] As a probabilistic model, the CQI has the potential to ‚Äúincorrectly‚Äù apply protection. False negatives and false positives could restrict a resting D-Peg order‚Äôs discretion in categories 3 + 4 respectively, preventing trades that might have been stable or even in the resting order‚Äôs favor. Despite the potential for these missed opportunities, IEX is able to trade more stable midpoint volume than any other exchange.[3] Marketable-to-mid meaning ‚Äúpriced at least as aggressively as the midpoint of the NBBO.‚Äù Such orders are eligible to transact with resting D-Peg orders.[4] In thinly-quoted names, there is often a single stock exchange at the NBB/NBO. As a result, quote changes are often atomic events that are less predictable. For more, see ‚Äúlonely quotes‚Äù here.About IEX ExchangeIEX Exchange is a U.S. stock exchange designed to provide superior execution quality and set a new standard for trading. title: Increase your IPO Allotment Chances as a Retail Investor
text: With the decreasing interest rates in bank account deposits, post office deposits, ever-increasing prices of real estate, precious metals, and other ‚Äúsafe‚Äù investment tools, the population is slowly moving their investments towards the stock market.We all know, one of the easiest ways of getting good returns from the stock market is through IPOs(Initial Public Offerings). Companies usually target their IPOs at times of bull rally in the market, when there is high liquidity and people are struggling to find good stocks at reasonable prices. Hence, whenever there is an IPO of a fundamentally strong company coming up in the market, there is a lot of hype, and the IPO is heavily oversubscribed. Yes, there was crazy oversubscription for fundamentally good stocks(at the time of their IPOs) like IRCTC, SBI Cards, Happiest Minds, and a lot more.Most of us are left out with no allotment. However, there are a few tips and tricks that can be followed to increase your chances of allotment:Avoid Technical ErrorsThough most of the trading applications, Demat accounts are well built reactive web applications that help us to minimize human typing errors with their on the go validations, these points are still worth mentioning. Avoid errors in name, PAN number, bank details, etc. If you are applying through ASBA, double check your details like DP id, Demat account number, etc. Make sure the number of shares you apply for is a multiple of the defined number of shares per lot. Also, make sure you do not apply lesser or greater than the range of the number of shares allowed for Retail Investors.Maintain sufficient bank balance before allotmentSome banks block the amount which you are willing to spend to apply for the IPO. However, some do not block any amount and if you do not maintain adequate bank balance, your application will get rejected.One application per PAN numberWhether you have multiple Demat accounts or a single account, make sure that you apply for the IPO only once from just one of your Demat accounts. Multiple applications from one or many Demat accounts using the same PAN number will get all your applications rejected.Apply from multiple Demat accounts through different PAN numbersCreate Demat accounts in the name of your family members, relatives, or friends with their Demat account and you can make applications from their Demat accounts with their PAN numbers. Ensure it is still one application per PAN number.Always apply at the cut-off priceWhen IPOs are oversubscribed, they are going to come at the cut-off price. Avoid defining some price of your own to make sure your application is not rejected.Avoid application on the last day of the issueMost of the QIBs and FIIs and also the Retail Investors do their subscriptions on the last day of the issue based on the market sentiments. This means, there is a lot of load on the bank servers, trading application, etc. which may cause technical problems like UPI mandate notifications not coming up, OTP SMS not coming up, etc. which might make your application invalid. It is always better to apply before-hand, usually IPO sentiments on fundamentally strong companies do not change till the end of the issue date. However, if you have applied and you see that sentiments are looking bad, it may be possible to cancel your application.Apply for IPO allotment reservation quotaVery often, a good amount of shares are reserved for shareholders of the parent company, employees, etc. If you have that privilege, you can make use of it and increase your chances of allocation. You can even buy the parent company‚Äôs share for the short term(within the record date) and then apply for the IPO in the shareholder category. However, this technique may backfire if the parent company is highly favored in the market, in that case, there will be a higher number of people applying for the shareholder category and a lesser number of people in the unreserved category. Whether to apply this technique or not is based on the number of shares reserved for the reserved category and the parent company.Written byKunal KarmakarEnthusiastic Software EngineerFollowStock MarketIPOStock Market TipsInvestmentStock ExchangeMore from Kunal KarmakarFollowEnthusiastic Software EngineerMore From MediumHow to Survive on $800 a MonthKesia Alexandra in The StartupNew York‚Äôs Wack Pet Trust LawAndrea ColemanFree Financial Resources for Better Money in 2020Angely Mercado in Cheap AFStudent Loan Debt: A Sad State of the UnionThe Angry GradSharpe Ratio‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäBigger Isn‚Äôt Necessarily BetterEng Guan Lim in Data Driven InvestorCan You Make A Living As a Day Trader?Jamie Murray in Understanding MoneyMonopoly: Board Game or Our Current Reality?Carter Kilmann in Bacon BitsInvestment Strategies from a Silicon Valley Hedge FundNathan Breiner in The AscentAboutHelpLegalGet the Medium app

title: STOCK EXCHANGE OR STOCK INDEX?
text: The Difference Between a Stock Exchange and a Stock IndexYou may hear talk about stock exchanges and stock indices, and it‚Äôs easy to confuse them as the same thing. In this article, we highlight what each means and show why they are relevant to your investing strategy. A stock index is a list of stocks that is created to gauge the whole market, or even a sector of the market. A stock exchange, on the other hand, is the actual place where you can buy and sell stocks, bonds, and other securities that are listed on different indices.Let‚Äôs look at some details below.Stock IndicesAn index groups together company stocks in order to measure changes in the broader stock market, or in a sector of the stock market. There are famous examples that you may have heard of, such as the FTSE100. This index includes the 100 largest companies in the UK.Indices can also exist for smaller companies, for example the Alternative Investment Market (AIM), which is a subsidiary of the London Stock Exchange and allows smaller companies to raise capital with less restrictions. Each index has its own measure of how exactly it‚Äôs valued. This could be based on the cumulative share price of the individual stocks, or it could be based on the total market capitalisation in the index. Some even combine both measurements. As the individual share prices or market caps move up and down within the index, the total value of the individual index changes too.Stock ExchangesIf you actually want to buy a stock, then you‚Äôll have to turn to an exchange. One of the largest and most famous stock exchanges in the world is headquartered in the UK: the London Stock Exchange. There are exchanges all over the world, including the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, the B3 in Brazil, and the New York Stock Exchange in the US.
